Full twenty years have roll'd, ye rhiming band,</br>Since first I dipp'd in ink my trembling hand,</br>For much it trembled, tho' th' obliging few,</br>Who judge with candour, prais'd the sketch I drew;</br>And Echo, answering from the public voice,</br>Indulg'd as genius, what I fear'd was choice.

At length, arriv'd at these maturer years</br>So rarely rais'd by hope, or sunk by fears,</br>I rest in peace; or scribble if I please:</br>In point of wealth not affluent, but at ease;</br>In point of what the world and you call fame,</br>(I judge but by conjecture) much the same.

But whether right or wrong I judge, to you</br>It matters not:  the following fact is true.</br>From nobler names, and great in each degree,</br>The pension'd Laurel has devolv'd to me.</br>To me, ye Bards; and, what you'll scarce conceive,</br>Or, at the best, unwillingly believe,</br>Howe'er unworthily I wear the crown,</br>Unask'd it came, and from a hand unknown.

Then, since my King, and Patron have thought fit</br>To place me on the throne of modern wit,</br>My grave advice, my brethren, hear at large;</br>As Bishops to their Clergy give their charge,</br>Tho' many a Priest, who listens, might afford</br>Perhaps more solid counsel to my Lord.

To YOU, ye guardians of the sacred fount,</br>Deans and Archdeacons of the double mount,</br>That thro' our realms intestine broils may cease,</br>My first, and last advice is, "Keep the peace!"</br>What is't to you, that half the town admire</br>False sense, false strength, false softness, or false fire?</br>Through heav'n's void concave let the meteors blaze,</br>He hurts his own, who wounds another's bays.</br>What is't to you that numbers place your name</br>First, fifth, or twentieth, in the lists of fame?</br>Old Time will settle all your claims at once,</br>Record the Genius, and forget the Dunce.

It boots us much to know, observers say,</br>Of what materials Nature form'd our clay;</br>From what strange beast Prometheus' plastic art</br>Purloin'd the particle which rules the heart.</br>If milky softness, gliding through the veins,</br>Incline the Muse to panegyric strains,</br>Insipid lays our kindest friends may lull,</br>Be very moral, yet be very dull.</br>If bile prevails, and temper dictates satire,</br>Our wit is spleen, our virtue is ill-nature;</br>With it's own malice arm'd we combat evil,</br>As zeal for God's sake sometimes plays the devil.</br>O mark it well!  does Pride affect to reign</br>The solitary tyrant of the brain?</br>Or Vanity exert her quick'ning flame,</br>Stuck round with ears that listen after fame?</br>O to these points let strict regard be given,</br>Nor "KNOW THYSELF" in vain descend from Heaven.

Do Critics teize you? — with a smile I speak,</br>Nor would suppose my brethren were so weak.</br>'Tis on ourselves and not our foes, or friends,</br>Our future fame, or infamy depends.</br>Let envy point, or malice wing the darts,</br>They only wound us in our mortal parts.</br>Besides, 'tis much too late to go to school,</br>Grown men will judge by Nature's noblest rule,</br>Admire true beauties, and slight faults excuse,</br>Not learn to dance from Journals and Reviews.
If fools traduce you, and your works decry,</br>As many fools will rate your worth too high;</br>Then balance the account, and fairly take</br>The cool report which men of judgment make.

In writing, as in life, he foils the foe,</br>Who, conscious of his strength, forgives the blow.</br>They court the insult who but seem afraid:</br>And then, by answering, you promote the trade,</br>And give them, what their own weak claims deny,</br>A chance for future laughter, or a sigh.

YOU, who as yet, unsullied by the Press,</br>Hang o'er your labours in their virgin dress;</br>And YOU, who late the public taste have hit,</br>And still enjoy the honey-moon of wit,</br>Attentive hear me:  grace may still abound,</br>Whoever preaches, if the doctrine's sound.

If Nature prompts you, or if friends persuade,</br>Why write; but ne'er pursue it as a trade.</br>And seldom publish:  manuscripts disarm</br>The censor's frown, and boast an added charm,</br>Enhance their worth by seeming to retire,</br>For what but few can prate of, all admire.

Who trade in verse, alas, we rarely find,</br>The public grateful, as the Muses kind.</br>From constant feasts like sated guests we steal,</br>And tir'd of tickling lose all power to feel.</br>'Tis novelty we want; and that in view</br>We praise stale matter, so the Bard be new;</br>Or from known Bards with exstacy receive</br>Each pert new whim they almost blush to give.

A life of writing, unless wond'rous short,</br>No wit can brave, no genius can support.</br>Some soberer province for your business chuse,</br>Be that your helmet, and your plume the Muse.</br>Through Fame's long rubric, down from Chaucer's time,</br>Few fortunes have been rais'd by lofty rhime.</br>And, when our toils success no longer crowns,</br>What shelter find we from a world in frowns?</br>O'er each distress, which vice or folly brings,</br>Tho' Charity extend her healing wings,</br>No Maudlin Hospitals are yet assign'd</br>For slip-shod Muses of the vagrant kind;</br>Where anthems might succeed to satires keen,</br>And hymns of penitence to songs obscene.

What refuge then remains? — with gracious grin</br>Some practis'd Bookseller invites you in.</br>Where luckless Bards, condemn'd to court the town,</br>(Not for their parents' vices, but their own!)</br>Write gay conundrums with an aching head,</br>Or earn by defamation daily bread,</br>Or, friendless, shirtless, penniless complain,</br>Not of the world's, but "Caelia's cold disdain."
Lords of their workhouse see the tyrants sit</br>Brokers in books, and stock-jobbers in wit,</br>Beneath whose lash, oblig'd to write or fast,</br>Our confessors and martyrs breathe their last!

And can ye bear such insolence? — away,</br>For shame; plough, dig, turn pedlars, drive the dray;</br>With minds indignant each employment suits,</br>Our fleets want sailors, and our troops recruits;</br>And many a dirty street, on Thames's side,</br>Is yet by stool and brush unoccupied.

Time was when Poets play'd the thorough game,</br>Swore, drank, and bluster'd, and blasphem'd for fame.</br>The first in brothels with their punk and Muse;</br>Your toast, ye Bards?  "Parnassus and the stews!"</br>Thank Heaven the times are chang'd; no Poet now</br>Need roar for Bacchus, or to Venus bow.</br>'Tis our own fault if Fielding's lash we feel,</br>Or, like French wits, begin with the Bastile.

Ev'n in those days some few escap'd their fate,</br>By better judgment, or a longer date,</br>And rode, like buoys, triumphant o'er the tide.</br>Poor Otway in an ale-house dos'd, and died!</br>While happier Southern, tho' with spots of yore,</br>Like Plato's hovering spirits, crusted o'er,</br>Liv'd every mortal vapour to remove,</br>And to our admiration join'd our love.

Light lie his funeral turf! — for you, who join</br>His decent manners to his art divine,</br>Would ye (whilst, round you, toss the proud and vain</br>Convuls'd with feeling, or with giving pain)</br>Indulge the Muse in innocence and ease,</br>And tread the flowery path of life in peace?</br>Avoid all authors. — What!  th' illustrious few,</br>Who shunning Fame have taught her to pursue</br>Fair Virtue's heralds? — yes, I say again,</br>Avoid all authors, 'till you've read the men.</br>Full many a peevish, envious, slandering elf,</br>Is, in his works, Benevolence itself.</br>For all mankind unknown, his bosom heaves,</br>He only injures those with whom he lives.</br>Read then the Man:  Does truth his actions guide,</br>Exempt from petulance, exempt from pride?</br>To social duties does his heart attend,</br>As Son, as Father, Husband, Brother, Friend?</br>Do those who know him love him?  if they do,</br>You've my permission, you may love him too.

But chief avoid the boist'rous roaring sparks,</br>The sons of fire! — you'll know them by their marks.</br>Fond to be heard they always court a croud,</br>And, tho' 'tis borrow'd nonsense, talk it loud.</br>One epithet supplies their constant chime,</br>Damn'd bad, damn'd good, damn'd low, and damn'd sublime!</br>But most in quick short repartee they shine</br>Of local humour; or from plays purloin</br>Each quaint stale scrap which every subject hits,</br>'Till fools almost imagine, they are wits.</br>Hear them on Shakespear!  there the foam, they rage!</br>Yet taste not half the beauties of HIS page,</br>Nor see that Art, as well as Nature, strove</br>To place HIM foremost in th' Aonian grove.</br>For there, there only, where the sisters meet,</br>HIS Genius triumphs, and the work's compleat.

Or would ye sift more near these sons of fire,</br>'Ti Garrick, and not Shakspear they admire.</br>Without his breath, inspiring every thought,</br>They ne'er perhaps had known what Shakespear wrote;</br>Without his eager, his becoming zeal,</br>To teach them, tho' they scarce know why, to feel,</br>A crude unmeaning mass had Johnson been,</br>And a dead letter Shakespear's noblest scene.

O come the time, when diffidence again</br>Shall bind our youth in Nature's modest chain!</br>Born in a happier age, and happier clime,</br>Old Sophocles had merit, in his time;</br>And so, no doubt, howe'er we flout his plays,</br>Had poor Euripides, in former days.</br>Not like the moderns we confess; but yet</br>Some seeming faults we surely might forget,</br>Because 'twould puzzle even the wise to show</br>Whether those faults were real faults, or no.
To all true merit give it's just applause,</br>The worst have beauties, and the best have flaws.</br>Greek, French, Italian, English, great or small,</br>I own my frailty, I admire them all.

There are, mistaking prejudice for taste,</br>Who on one species all their rapture waste.</br>Tho', various as the flowers which paint the year,</br>In rainbow charms the changeful Nine appear,</br>The different beauties coyly they admit,</br>And to one standard would confine our wit.</br>Some MANNER'D VERSE delights; while some can raise</br>To fairy FICTION their extatic gaze,</br>Admire PURE POETRY, and revel there</br>On sightless forms, and pictures of the air!</br>Some hate all RHIME; some seriously deplore</br>That Milton wants that one enchantment more.</br>Tir'd with th' ambiguous tale, or antique phrase,</br>O'er Spenser's happiest paintings, loveliest lays,</br>Some heedless pass:  while some with transport view</br>Each quaint old word, which scarce Eliza knew;</br>And, eager as the fancied knights, prepare</br>The lance, and combat in ideal war</br>Dragons of lust, and giants of despair.

Why be it so; and what each thinks the test</br>Let each enjoy:  but not condemn the rest.</br>Readers there are of every class prepar'd,</br>Each village teems, each hamlet has its Bard</br>Who gives the tone, and all th' inferior fry,</br>Like the great vulgar here, will join the cry.</br>But be it mine with every Bard to glow,</br>And taste his raptures genuine as they flow,</br>Through all the Muse's wilds to rove along</br>From plaintive Elegy to Epic song;</br>And, if the sense be just, the numbers clear,</br>And the true colouring of the work be there,</br>Again, subdued by Truth's ingenous call,</br>I own my frailty, I admire them all.

Nor think I, with the mob, that Nature now</br>No longer warms the soil where laurels grow.</br>'Tis true Our Poets in repose delight,</br>And, wiser than their fathers, seldom write.</br>Yet I, but I forbear for prudent ends,</br>Could name a list, and half of them my friends,</br>For whom posterity it's wreaths shall twine,</br>And it's own Bards neglect, to honour mine.

Their Poets in their turn will grieve, and swear,</br>Perhaps with truth, no Patron lends an ear.</br>Complaints of times when merit wants reward</br>Descend like similies from Bard to Bard;</br>We copy our distress from Greece and Rome;</br>As in our Northern lays their flowrets bloom.</br>We feel their breezes, and their heats we burn,</br>And plead prescription to rejoice or mourn.

All present times are bad:  then cast your eyes</br>Where fairy scenes of bliss in prospect rise.</br>As fond enthusiasts o'er the western main</br>With eager ken, prophetical in vain,</br>See multitudes from every land</br>Grow pure by blending, virtuous by command;</br>'Till, phoenix-like, a new bright world of gold</br>Springs from the dregs and refuse of the old.

I'm no enthusiast, yet with joy can trace</br>Some gleams of sunshine for the tuneful race.</br>If Monarchs listen when the Muses woo,</br>Attention wakes, and nations listen too.</br>The Bard grows rapturous, who was dumb before,</br>And every fresh-plum'd eagle learns to soar!

Friend of the finer arts, when Aegypt saw</br>Her second Ptolemy give Science law,</br>Each Genus waken'd from his dead repose,</br>The column swell'd, the pile majestic rose,</br>Exact proportion borrow'd strength from ease,</br>And use was taught by elegance to please.</br>Along the breathing walls, as fancy flow'd,</br>The sculpture soften'd, and the picture glow'd,</br>Heroes reviv'd in animated stone,</br>The groves grew vocal, and the Pleiads shone!</br>Old Nilus rais'd his head, and wond'ring cried,</br>Long live the King!  my Patron, and my Pride!</br>Secure of endless praise, behold, I bear</br>My grateful suffrage to my Sovereign's ear.</br>Tho' war shall rage, tho' Time shall level all,</br>Yon colours sicken, and yon columns fall,</br>Tho' art's dear treasures feed the wasting flame,</br>And the proud volume sinks, an empty name,</br>Tho' Plenty may desert this copious vale,</br>My streams be scatter'd, or my fountain fail,</br>Yet Ptolemy has liv'd:  the world has known</br>A King of arts, a Patron on a throne.</br>Ev'n utmost Britain shall his name adore,</br>"And Nile be sung, when Nile shall flow no more."

One rule remains.  Nor shun nor court the great,</br>Your truest center is that middle state</br>From whence with ease th' observing eye may go</br>To all which soars above, or sinks below.</br>'Tis yours all manners to have tried, or known,</br>T' adopt all virtues, yet retain your own:</br>To stem the tide, where thoughtless crowds are hurl'd,</br>The firm spectators of a bustling world!

Thus arm'd, proceed:  the breezes court your wing.</br>Go range all Helicon, taste every spring;</br>From varying nature cull th' innoxious spoil,</br>And, whilst amusement sooths the generous toil,</br>Let puzzled Critics with judicious spite</br>Descant on what you can, or can not write.</br>True to yourselves, not anxious for renown,</br>Nor court  the world's applause, nor dread it's frown.</br>Guard your own breasts, and be the bulwark there</br>To know no envy, and no malice fear.</br>At least you'll find, thus Stoic-like prepar'd,</br>That Verse and Virtue are their own reward.</br>
